title: W02-1602

sentences.text: Coedition of a natural language text and its representation in some interlingual form seems the best and simplest way to share text revision across languages .
For various reasons , UNL graphs are the best candidates in this context .
We are developing a prototype where , in the simplest sharing scenario , naive users interact directly with the text in their language -LRB- L0 -RRB- , and indirectly with the associated graph .
The modified graph is then sent to the UNL-L0 deconverter and the result shown .
If is is satisfactory , the errors were probably due to the graph , not to the deconverter , and the graph is sent to deconverters in other languages .
Versions in some other languages known by the user may be displayed , so that improvement sharing is visible and encouraging .
As new versions are added with appropriate tags and attributes in the original multilingual document , nothing is ever lost , and cooperative working on a document is rendered feasible .

On the internal side , liaisons are established between elements of the text and the graph by using broadly available resources such as a LO-English or better a L0-UNL dictionary , a morphosyntactic parser of L0 , and a canonical graph2tree transformation .

Establishing a `` best '' correspondence between the '' UNL-tree + L0 '' and the '' MS-L0 structure '' , a lattice , may be done using the dictionary and trying to align the tree and the selected trajectory with as few crossing liaisons as possible .
A central goal of this research is to merge approaches from pivot MT , interactive MT , and multilingual text authoring .

Entity-unl_graph.label: UNL graphs
Entity-unl_graph.description: Interlingual representations of natural language texts, used for sharing text revisions across languages and facilitating cooperative working on multilingual documents.

Entity-unl-l0.label: UNL-L0
Entity-unl-l0.description: The UNL-L0 is an algorithm for converting natural language text into its representation in some interlingual form, used as part of a prototype for sharing and revising multilingual documents.

Entity-this_context.label: this context
Entity-this_context.description: The scenario where United Nations Linguistics (UNL) graphs are used as the best candidates for sharing text revision across languages.

Entity-liaison_are_established_between_e.label: liaisons are established between elements of the text and the graph by using broadly available resources such as a LO-English or better a L0-UNL dictionary, a morphosyntactic parser of L0, and a canonical graph2tree transformation

Entity-liaison_are_established_between_e.description: The process of establishing connections (liaisons) between textual elements and their graphical representations.

Entity-we_are_developing_a_prototype.description: A prototype for sharing multilingual documents across languages, allowing naive users to interact directly with text in their language and indirectly with an associated graph.

Entity-deconverters_in_other_language.label: deconverters in other languages
Entity-deconverters_in_other_language.description: Software systems or tools designed for converting Universal Networking Language (UNL) graphs into natural language texts, operating across multiple languages.

Entity-unl-tree.label: UNL-tree
Entity-unl-tree.description: A data structure representing a lattice that corresponds between UNL (Universal Networking Language) and L0, used for merging approaches from pivot machine translation, interactive machine translation, and multilingual text authoring.

Entity-unl-l0_deconverter.label: UNL-L0 deconverter
Entity-unl-l0_deconverter.description: A software system responsible for converting UNL graphs into their original L0 language representation.

Entity-coedition.label: Coedition
Entity-coedition.description: A method for sharing text revisions across languages by coediting a natural language text with its representation in an interlingual form.

Entity-unl.label: UNL
Entity-unl.description: A graph-based interlingua language or organization that enables communication and information exchange across different languages.

summary: Coedition of a natural language text and its representation in some interlingual form seems the best and simplest way to share text revision across languages . For various reasons , UNL graphs are the best candidates in this context . We are developing a prototype where , in the simplest sharing scenario , naive users interact directly with the text in their language -LRB- L0 -RRB- , and indirectly with the associated graph . The modified graph is then sent to the UNL-L0 deconverter and the result shown . If is is satisfactory , the errors were probably due to the graph , not to the deconverter , and the graph is sent to deconverters in other languages . Versions in some other languages known by the user may be displayed , so that improvement sharing is visible and encouraging . As new versions are added with appropriate tags and attributes in the original multilingual document , nothing is ever lost , and cooperative working on a document is rendered feasible . On the internal side , liaisons are established between elements of the text and the graph by using broadly available resources such as a LO-English or better a L0-UNL dictionary , a morphosyntactic parser of L0 , and a canonical graph2tree transformation . Establishing a `` best '' correspondence between the '' UNL-tree + L0 '' and the '' MS-L0 structure '' , a lattice , may be done using the dictionary and trying to align the tree and the selected trajectory with as few crossing liaisons as possible . A central goal of this research is to merge approaches from pivot MT , interactive MT , and multilingual text authoring .

Predicate-is_represented_as.label: is represented as
Predicate-is_represented_as.description: The predicate 'is represented as' indicates a mapping or correspondence between two entities: the subject (a natural language text) and the object (its representation in some interlingual form). This relationship suggests that there exists an equivalent, standardized, or formalized version of the original text, which can be used for further processing, analysis, or communication. The predicate highlights a transformation from one linguistic format to another, implying a lossless translation or encoding process.

Predicate-shares.label: shares
Predicate-shares.description: The predicate 'shares' indicates that two or more entities are connected by some common aspect, attribute, or characteristic. In this sense, it represents a relationship of similarity, equivalence, or co-occurrence between the subject and object.

Predicate-developing.label: developing
Predicate-developing.description: The predicate 'developing' indicates that the subject is actively creating or improving something towards its intended form or functionality. It implies a process of growth, refinement, or maturation from an initial state to a more advanced one.

Predicate-where.label: where
Predicate-where.description: The 'where' predicate indicates the circumstances or context under which a particular action, situation, or process occurs. It provides additional information about the setting, environment, or conditions that are relevant to the subject's activity.

Predicate-shown_as.label: shown as
Predicate-shown_as.description: Indicates a representation or visualization of something (the subject), which conveys its essence or characteristics to convey meaning. The predicate 'shown as' establishes an equivalence between the subject and the object, suggesting that the latter serves as a visual or conceptual proxy for the former.

Predicate-sent_to.label: sent to
Predicate-sent_to.description: The predicate 'sent to' indicates a transfer or transmission of something (e.g. information, data, objects) from the subject to the object. It implies a movement or conveyance of content, concepts, or entities from one entity to another.

Predicate-due_to.label: due to
Predicate-due_to.description: The predicate 'due to' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the state or condition described by the subject exists as a direct result of, or in relation to, the entity or circumstance denoted by the object.

Predicate-may_be_displayed.label: may be displayed
Predicate-may_be_displayed.description: The predicate 'may be displayed' indicates a potential relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the information or content represented by the subject can potentially appear in some form (e.g., text, image, video) as described by the object. The connection implies an opportunity for the subject to be presented or shown in a particular context.

Predicate-so_that.label: so that
Predicate-so_that.description: The predicate 'so that' indicates a purpose or intention behind an action. It connects the subject (the entity performing the action) to the object (the outcome or result of the action), implying that the action is taken in order to achieve the specified goal.

Predicate-renders_feasible.label: renders feasible
Predicate-renders_feasible.description: The predicate 'renders feasible' indicates that the subject enables or makes possible the object. It suggests a causal relationship where the subject's existence, action, or state allows for or facilitates the possibility of achieving or accomplishing something related to the object.

Predicate-and.label: and
Predicate-and.description: The predicate 'and' indicates that two or more clauses are being conjoined to form a single statement. It serves as a logical connector, linking the subject and object by emphasizing their simultaneous existence, equivalence, or co-occurrence.

Predicate-is_used_by.label: is used by
Predicate-is_used_by.description: The predicate 'is used by' indicates the relationship between an entity (the subject) that provides or facilitates access to resources, tools, methods, or processes (the object), which are then employed for a specific purpose.

Predicate-corresponds_to.label: corresponds to
Predicate-corresponds_to.description: The predicate 'corresponds to' indicates a relationship where the subject (a linguistic representation or model) has an equivalent or analogous form, structure, or meaning with respect to the object. This connection suggests that there exists a mapping or alignment between the two entities, allowing for translation, transformation, or interpretation of one into another.

Predicate-is_to_merge_approaches_from.label: is to merge approaches from
Predicate-is_to_merge_approaches_from.description: This predicate indicates that the subject intends or aims to combine or integrate different methods, techniques, or perspectives (represented by the object) towards a unified goal. The phrase 'from' suggests a source or origin of these approaches being merged.

Predicate-used_as_part.label: used as part
Predicate-used_as_part.description: The predicate 'used as part' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g., UNL graphs) has some portion or aspect that serves a specific purpose, function, or role within a larger context. The object (e.g., UNL-LO0) represents this part or aspect, which is being utilized for its intended purpose.

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: The predicate 'are' indicates a relationship of equivalence or similarity between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject and object share common characteristics, properties, or attributes, implying a sense of unity, coherence, or sameness.

Predicate-are_used_as.label: are used as
Predicate-are_used_as.description: The predicate 'are used as' indicates a relationship where the subject (a concept or entity) has its meaning, function, or purpose defined by the object (another concept, term, or category). In this sense, the subject's identity or significance is tied to how it relates to the object.

Predicate-For_various_reasons__UNL_graph.label: For various reasons , UNL graphs are the best candidates **in this context** . We are developing a prototype where ...
Predicate-For_various_reasons__UNL_graph.description: This predicate indicates that the subject (e.g., 'We are developing a prototype') is selecting or considering the object ('UNL graphs') as the best option for a specific purpose or context, which is further specified by the phrase 'in this context'.

Predicate-establish.label: establish
Predicate-establish.description: To establish means to create a connection or relationship between two entities (subject and object), typically involving the creation of a stable or formalized link, which enables further interaction, understanding, or integration.

Predicate-established_in.label: established in
Predicate-established_in.description: The predicate 'established in' indicates the context or framework within which something exists, operates, or has been set up. It implies a sense of foundation, basis, or underlying structure that enables or facilitates the existence or functioning of the subject.

Predicate-develop.label: develop
Predicate-develop.description: To develop means to bring something into being, shape or form through gradual growth, evolution, refinement, or improvement. It implies the subject's intentional effort and investment in transforming an idea, concept, or initial state into a more mature, complex, or sophisticated entity.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject concept is related to another concept (the object), which provides more general or overarching information about the subject. This relationship suggests that the subject can be classified, categorized, or subsumed under the broader term.
